## Yield to Maturity
$$ P = \frac{CF_1}{(1+y)}+\frac{CF_2}{(1+y)^2}+...+\frac{CF_T}{(1+y)^T} $$ 

For bonds, the cash flows are usually fixed coupon payments, so this reduces to:

$$ P = \frac{C}{(1+y)}+\frac{C}{(1+y)^2}+...+\frac{C}{(1+y)^T}+\frac{FACE}{(1+y)^T}$$

where $C$ is the coupon payment of the bond.

## YTM versus Expected Returns

**For a risky bond, YTM $\neq$ expected return!**

- YTM is the IRR of a bond based on **promised** cash flows.

![](../images/corp_bond_tree.png)

. . .

$$E[r] = (1-p_{\text{default}})\cdot YTM + p_{\text{default}}\cdot r_{\text{default}}.$$

**YTM overestimates expected returns for risky bonds.**
